texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This well-known species has a deep body with the blunt rounded head typical of all stumpnose and after which the common name is derived. It can be distinguished from other regional stumpnose by its silvery body marked by 6–7 faint dark vertical bars.
Up to 65 cm total length and a mass of up to 3 kg.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.

Adults found in shoals both in sandy and rocky areas from the low water mark to a depth of 120 m. Juveniles common in estuaries and in the surf zone of beaches and may occur in mixed shoals with the closely-related Cape stumpnose. Tend to move offshore in winter and concentrate inshore in summer. Can reach an age of about 21 years.

Small juveniles feed mostly on zooplankton and later on filamentous algae and small crustaceans. After their molars develop at about 4 cm they start to take shelled mollusks, larger crustaceans and worms. Adults feed on bivalves, worms and a variety of crustaceans.
Do not change sex. Reach sexual maturity as a length of about 17–23 cm (2-4 years of age). Spawn inshore in spring and summer (August to February). Eggs develop in the plankton.

Body shape and habits similar to Cape stumpnose R. holubi, but that species lacks the dark vertical bars and instead has a horizontal golden band running along the side from head to tail. Could at first glance be confused with the White steenbras Lithognathus lithognathus and perhaps Sand steenbras L. mormyrus as both species also have vertical bars but long and tapering mouths instead of a blunt rounded head.
